awd_titl_txt: Boston University Conference on Language Development 2017-2021
awd_abstract_narration:
The Boston University Conference on Language Development (BUCLD) will be held at Boston University each November from 2017 through 2021. BUCLD is an internationally recognized meeting of researchers in language acquisition and development, including first and second language acquisition, language disorders, bilingualism, and literacy development. Now in its forty-second year, BUCLD promotes the progress of science by providing a major venue for dissemination of scholarly findings, for initiation and development of collaborations, and for professional networking. The conference consists of approximately 190 presentations selected through peer review, as well as invited keynote and plenary speakers, two symposia on topics of current interest, a research funding workshop, a professionalization workshop for students and postdoctoral scholars, and a publisher exhibit. Attendees number over 500 researchers from around the world, from undergraduates up through senior faculty. Full ASL interpreting coverage is provided throughout the conference, and conference proceedings are published soon after the conference. Since 1976, the faculty and students of Boston University have organized and run the conference; Dr. Charles Chang, Dr. Sudha Arunachalam, and Dr. Paul Hagstrom lead the team of organizers for the 2017 conference.  

Funding from the National Science Foundation will support education and enhance accessibility, diversity, and inclusion at BUCLD by subsidizing student travel, including that of underrepresented minorities, and the time of the student organizers of the conference, graduate students in Linguistics and allied fields. Support for student travel will allow student contributions, regularly among the highest-rated abstract submissions, to be presented at the conference without undue hardship and will increase the exposure of students to the top research and researchers in the field in a friendly and interactive environment. Furthermore, support for student organizers will allow BUCLD to continue to play an important role in training students as future professionals, including undergraduates and women.

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in five successful iterations of the Boston University Conference on Language Development (BUCLD), BUCLD 42 to BUCLD 46. BUCLD 42 (held November 3-5, 2017), BUCLD 43 (held November 1-4, 2018), and BUCLD 44 (held November 7-10, 2019) took place in person, while BUCLD 45 (held November 5-8, 2020) and BUCLD 46 (held November 4-7, 2021) took place as virtual conferences, the first fully remote iterations of BUCLD in the conference's history.

Each year, the conference consisted of approximately 180 presentations selected through peer review by a panel of about 200 distinguished experts in the field, as well as invited keynote and plenary addresses, a symposium on a topic of current interest, a research funding workshop and consultation hours (facilitated by representatives from the National Science Foundation and the National Institutes of Health), a professional development workshop for students and postdoctoral scholars, and a sponsors' exhibit. In 2020-2021, submitted conference presentations were prerecorded (and thus could be viewed asynchronously), but programmed into the conference schedule with synchronous question-and-answer sessions; the other components of the conference were presented synchronously (and recorded, for later asynchronous viewing). Every conference session, including at the virtual BUCLD 45-46, was covered by professional ASL interpreters. Totaling over 3900 attendees in all, attendance at BUCLD 42-46 was by far the highest it has ever been in the history of the conference. This was largely due to strong student attendance, facilitated by highly subsidized (or free, in 2020-2021) student registration. Conference proceedings were published each year by Cascadilla Press, in print as well as online open-access.

Grant funding supported two specific components of the conference: the student organizing committee and student travel awards. Almost entirely student-run, BUCLD 42-46 were organized principally by an organizing committee comprising two student co-organizers, who oversaw all aspects of the conference, and a team of 7-8 other student committee chairs, who oversaw individual aspects of the conference such as hospitality, technology, sponsorship, finances, ASL interpreters, registration, social media, and volunteers. Their time was funded by stipends supported by this grant. In addition, many more (up to 100) students, primarily from language-related programs at BU, served as student volunteers at BUCLD 42-46, helping with a variety of tasks including chairing and moderating sessions, leading social events, updating computer files, and proofreading conference documents. Funding for student travel awards supported approximately 35 travel awards to student authors on accepted presentations and, for the virtual BUCLD 45-46, free registration for all student attendees.
